content.description: The best warm up for the area. Good moves on cool rail features, top out is usually a bit dirty. One of the first obvious walls that you come. The "down climb" is around the corner to the north.
content.location: Starting on the arete, climb the blue limestone via the good features, top out. To down climb, walk north along the top of the cliff band 100 feet or so until it levels out into the hillside.

content.description:
Located 3 feet left of Lee Faria. The crux is pulling off the ground, but with some balance and a long reach, the cool sloper on the arete is reachable.  

  Could be harder, I was told it was V10, but it seems like it's more trickery and balance than difficulty.
content.location: Starts on the shallow pockets at about shoulder level and shoots left towards the blunt arete. After grabbing the sloper on the arete, shoot for the good, right facing edge situated in a depression and go straight up. Top out.

content.description: This the best moderate at the TV Station (probably the only one too) A tricky, technical start leads to a committing finish.
content.location:
10 feet left of The V3, starts in an obvious corner on a shallow, tufa-like feature and continues up and left. There are two exits, the left being the highest quality.  

  You can also link this into The V3 for additional amusement. 

  Down climb is the same as per The Warm Up Wall

content.description: Another warm up for the harder stuff.
content.location: Starts on the obvious jug flake and continues up via sharper edges. 50 feet north of the Warm Up Wall

content.description:
The area classic hard problem. Involves heinous crimping and a difficult high step, which leads to very unnerving, delicate face moves over a potentially gnarly fall. If you blow it at the top, you could literally fall off the mountain or best case scenario, end up in a tree.  

  Apparently Matt Birch wouldn't even shoe up to try it because of it's intimidating appearance and narrow landing.
content.location:
10 feet right of The V6. Starts on a high right handed pinch (can be started 2 moves lower, but it's doubtful if it adds extra difficulty). Start the same as per Live Late Breaking News, but after latching the heinous right handed edge, veer left out onto the blank prow. Make the hard, delicate crimp moves and top out.  

  Dropping from the highest point will put you onto the pads, but blowing it is well...not encouraged.

content.description: A hard line that links the bottom portion of Lee Faria in to the top of The V6.
content.location: Starting high on a right handed pinch, make the big move up to a decent sloper and continue right via a terrible, right handed crimp. Establish your left hand on another marginal edge and shoot right into the flake feature and top out.

content.description: A small limestone bouldering area just north of Sandia Crest, consisting of perhaps the best quality limestone in the ABQ area. A great summer alternative to Big Block/The Temple/The Woodie due to it's shade and cool temps, not to mention it's not a dug out cave covered in glue and the problems actually top out. Keep in mind the area is small, although there is still some potential for new problems. Grade range is V1-V12 or enough to keep everyone busy for at least an afternoon. Definitely worth a visit.
